information:
The 2025 James Beard Awards ceremony is scheduled to take place on June 16, 2025, in Chicago. The James Beard Foundation has recently made efforts to enhance inclusivity and equity in its awards program. These changes include the introduction of new categories, such as Best New Bar, Outstanding Professional in Beverage Service, and Outstanding Professional in Cocktail Service, as well as a shift to a regional model for the Best Chef category.

Several women have been named as finalists for the 2025 James Beard Awards. Cassie Piuma of Sarma in Somerville, MA, is a finalist for the national award of Outstanding Chef. Other female finalists in regional categories include Sarah Thompson of Casa Playa in Las Vegas (Best Chef: Southwest), Amanda Shulman of Her Place Supper Club in Philadelphia (Best Chef: Mid-Atlantic), and Erin Miller of Urban Hearth in Cambridge (Best Chef: Northeast).

In the last ten award cycles for James Beard Outstanding Chef, women have won four times. Since 2020, the James Beard Foundation has implemented an equity initiative. Following this, the share of female winners in the regional Best Chef awards increased from approximately 30% before 2020 to around 55% in 2024. The winners of the Outstanding Chef award in 2023 (Rob Rubba) and 2024 (Michael Rafidi) were men.

forecast.time_left_until_outcome_known: Approximately 20 days until June 16, 2025, when the James Beard Awards ceremony is scheduled.
forecast.status_quo_outcome: Based on historical patterns, the Outstanding Chef award would go to a man, as has happened in the last two consecutive years (2023, 2024).
forecast.no_outcome_scenario: The other Outstanding Chef finalists, who are presumably men, win the award instead of Cassie Piuma. The judges may favor their culinary achievements, restaurant impact, or overall body of work over Piuma's credentials.
forecast.yes_outcome_scenario: Cassie Piuma of Sarma wins the Outstanding Chef award. Her presence as a finalist indicates strong credentials, and the James Beard Foundation's equity initiatives that have significantly impacted regional awards (increasing female winners from 30% to 55%) extend their influence to this national category.
forecast.rationale: The historical base rate shows women winning the Outstanding Chef award 40% of the time (4 out of 10 years). However, the recent trend shows men winning in both 2023 and 2024, suggesting either regression to the mean or that the equity initiatives haven't yet fully penetrated the most prestigious national category. The equity initiatives have demonstrably impacted regional awards (30% to 55% female winners), but Outstanding Chef may lag this trend as the most prestigious single award. Cassie Piuma's presence as a finalist is crucial - she has cleared a major hurdle and is clearly competitive. However, we don't know the total number of finalists or how many other women might be finalists. Typically there are around 5 finalists per category, which would give her roughly a 20% baseline chance if selection were random, but the 40% historical rate suggests women win at higher rates than random when they're competitive. My forecast balances the 40% historical base rate with the concerning recent 0/2 streak and the reality that top awards often lag diversity trends seen in lower-tier categories. The forecast isn't higher because of the recent male winners and uncertainty about her competition; it isn't lower because of the strong historical precedent, equity initiatives momentum, and her finalist status. I would update higher if information emerged showing multiple female finalists or strong insider buzz for Piuma; I would update lower if learning there are numerous male finalists with exceptional credentials.

prompt:
You are a professional forecaster interviewing for a job.

Your interview question is:
Will a woman win the 2025 James Beard Award for Outstanding Chef?

Question background:
[Here Are the 2025 James Beard Awards Restaurant, Chef, and Media Award Finalists](https://www.eater.com/24398769/2025-james-beard-awards-restaurant-chef-finalists)


This question's outcome will be determined by the specific criteria below. These criteria have not yet been satisfied:
This question resolves as **Yes** if a woman wins the 2025 James Beard Award for Outstanding Chef.




Your research assistant's report says:
The 2025 James Beard Awards ceremony is scheduled to take place on June 16, 2025, in Chicago. The James Beard Foundation has recently made efforts to enhance inclusivity and equity in its awards program. These changes include the introduction of new categories, such as Best New Bar, Outstanding Professional in Beverage Service, and Outstanding Professional in Cocktail Service, as well as a shift to a regional model for the Best Chef category.

Several women have been named as finalists for the 2025 James Beard Awards. Cassie Piuma of Sarma in Somerville, MA, is a finalist for the national award of Outstanding Chef. Other female finalists in regional categories include Sarah Thompson of Casa Playa in Las Vegas (Best Chef: Southwest), Amanda Shulman of Her Place Supper Club in Philadelphia (Best Chef: Mid-Atlantic), and Erin Miller of Urban Hearth in Cambridge (Best Chef: Northeast).

In the last ten award cycles for James Beard Outstanding Chef, women have won four times. Since 2020, the James Beard Foundation has implemented an equity initiative. Following this, the share of female winners in the regional Best Chef awards increased from approximately 30% before 2020 to around 55% in 2024. The winners of the Outstanding Chef award in 2023 (Rob Rubba) and 2024 (Michael Rafidi) were men.

Today is 2025-05-27.

Before answering you think:
(a) The time left until the outcome to the question is known.
(b) The status quo outcome if nothing changed.
(c) A brief description of a scenario that results in a No outcome.
(d) A brief description of a scenario that results in a Yes outcome.
(e) You write your rationale remembering that good forecasters put extra weight on the status quo outcome since the world changes slowly most of the time. Explain your reasoning and the evidence behind your forecast in detail. Summarise information your received from your research assistant that influences your forecast (if any). Explain why your forecast is not higher, and why it is not lower. Outline what would need to be true for you to update your forecast in either direction.
(f) The last thing you write is your final probabilistic forecast as a number between 0 and 100.

# OUTPUT SCHEMA
{
    "time_left_until_outcome_known": "string",
    "status_quo_outcome": "string",
    "no_outcome_scenario": "string",
    "yes_outcome_scenario": "string",
    "rationale": "string",
    "probability": "number" (0-100)
}
